7.speaker: Wyll
7.text: Men, women, children, all barred from entry. A damned travesty.

23.speaker: Narrator
23.text: *Your tadpole quivers, revealing your discussion with Mizora to Wyll.*

17.speaker: Wyll
17.text: Shit. Father's been taken - and Mizora's started to scheme.

62.speaker: Wyll
62.text: 'A devil of a proposal.' By all the hounds of the Hells, what is she planning?

21.speaker: Wyll
21.text: By the hounds of the Hells, what is she planning?

10.speaker: Player
10.text: Mizora's up to nothing good, that's for certain.

29.speaker: Wyll
29.text: Certainly not - but she's as inevitable as Toril's path around the sun.

86.speaker: Player
86.text: I have no idea, but I can't wait to find out.

34.speaker: Player
34.text: I have no idea, but I can't wait to find out - tomorrow night, if we're lucky.

65.speaker: Wyll
65.text: Hmph. A little too eager for my liking. Well -

40.speaker: Wyll
40.text: We'll have answers soon enough. Mizora's gone to camp. We should speak with her.

14.speaker: Wyll
14.text: We'll have answers soon enough. Let's talk to Mizora.

31.speaker: Player
31.text: Your father's involved, which means it's worth hearing her out.

26.speaker: Wyll
26.text: Mizora's always worth hearing out. That's what make her so dangerous.

9.speaker: Player
9.text: Where's Gortash taken your father, do you think?

87.speaker: Wyll
87.text: I couldn't even fathom a guess - though I doubt we'll need to wait long for answers.

8.speaker: Wyll
8.text: Let's make camp when we're able. Mizora will be waiting.

6.speaker: Wyll
6.text: I can already feel her tightening the leash. This might be my last chance to escape it.
6.context:
NodeContext: [Tom P] Pickup:
With a sense of urgency and strength

51.speaker: Wyll
51.text: Until then, may my father keep safe, whatever coop he's been flown to.

52.speaker: Wyll
52.text: We'll have answers soon enough. Let's talk to Mizora.

75.speaker: Player
75.text: You don't have a single clue? She's your patron, not mine.

79.speaker: Wyll
79.text: By all the hounds of the Hells, what is she planning?

28.speaker: Wyll
28.text: Of course she'd stick her infernal nose where it doesn't belong. Of course she's dreamt up some risible scheme.

39.speaker: Narrator
39.text: *Fury rages in Wyll's mind as his mind links to yours. He sees you take up arms against Gortash - and knows Grand Duke Ravengard's fate.*

38.speaker: Wyll
38.text: By the Ninth Hell of Baator, what devil must have possessed you, that you'd move against Gortash?!

63.speaker: Wyll
63.text: My father's fallen, all because you lost every lick of good sense!

32.speaker: Player
32.text: I'm sorry Wyll. I don't know what came over me.

70.speaker: Wyll
70.text: You're sorry? Shit. You didn't spill a jug of milk. You killed my father.

2.speaker: Player
2.text: I did what I had to. I was not about to bargain with that lunatic.

68.speaker: Wyll
68.text: You could have walked away, strategised, considered your options. You could have lied.

11.speaker: Wyll
11.text: Instead, you painted the audience hall with my father's blood.

54.speaker: Narrator
54.text: *A moment passes; your link to Wyll fades.*

41.speaker: Wyll
41.text: There will be no more more dancing, no more 'us'. Someday, I might forgive this. But I won't forget.

16.speaker: Wyll
16.text: Someday, I might forgive this. But I won't forget.

69.speaker: Player
69.text: A sacrifice worth making - we have another Netherstone.

35.speaker: Wyll
35.text: It was a sacrifice you should have avoided.

89.speaker: Player
89.text: Your father was every bit as dangerous as Gortash. I did this city a favour.

59.speaker: Wyll
59.text: Don't act like what you did was noble.

4.speaker: Wyll
4.text: My father is infected, same as us - or have you forgotten? If we can be cured, so could he.

56.speaker: Player
56.text: You know what Gortash did to me. He needed to die.

88.speaker: Wyll
88.text: Dammit, Karlach. Your vengeance was not worth my father's life.

48.speaker: Wyll
48.text: Unthinkable, to see my own father name Gortash the sole ruler of Baldur's Gate.

80.speaker: Wyll
80.text: Please, we need to speak with him. Maybe - maybe he can see reason...

49.speaker: Wyll
49.text: By the Ninth Hell of Baator, what devil must have possessed us, that we'd move against Gortash?!

64.speaker: Wyll
64.text: We could have walked away, strategised, considered our options. We could have lied.

73.speaker: Wyll
73.text: Instead, we painted the audience hall with my father's blood.

45.speaker: Player
45.text: We did what we had to. Do you think we should have bargained with that lunatic?

47.speaker: Wyll
47.text: I think we should have tamed our rage - not feed it, whet its claws, and set it loose!

27.speaker: Narrator
27.text: *A moment passes; your link to Wyll fades.*

20.speaker: Wyll
20.text: What becomes of the Blade of Frontiers when he slays the man he vowed to save? What pride should this city have for a son who kills its brightest star?

78.speaker: Player
78.text: I'm sorry Wyll. We should have found another way.

19.speaker: Wyll
19.context:
NodeContext: [Tom P] Pickup:
In the following line Wyll is angry, so this needs to build up to that delivery - a bitter sorry

50.speaker: Wyll
50.text: We had every chance to tame our rage - but we fed it, whet its claws, and let it loose.

12.speaker: Player
12.text: A sacrifice worth making - we have another Netherstone.

25.speaker: Wyll
25.text: It was a sacrifice we should have avoided.

61.speaker: Player
61.text: Your father was every bit as dangerous as Gortash. We did this city a favour.

30.speaker: Wyll
30.text: Don't act like what we did was noble.

37.speaker: Player
37.text: You know what Gortash did to me. He needed to die.

67.speaker: Wyll
67.text: Godsdammit, Karlach. You'd sacrifice my father just to have vengeance?

55.speaker: Wyll
55.text: Incredible. To hear my father voice speak those words - like a stranger wrapped in his flesh.

53.speaker: Wyll
53.text: But - there's still a glimmer of him in there, calling for release. I feel it, I know it.

81.speaker: Wyll
81.text: I won't let the Absolute keep him. This is my pledge.

13.speaker: Wyll
13.text: A decade ago, Baldur's Gate would have welcomed any- and everyone seeking refuge.

46.speaker: Wyll
46.text: Who would take in these souls, if not the jewel of Balduran?

1.speaker: Player
1.text: What a shame. Baldur's Gate has a responsibility to people in need.

5.speaker: Wyll
5.text: As long as Gortash is in charge, they'll be left shivering at the gates. All part of the plan, of course.

44.speaker: Wyll
44.text: To make this city a safe haven, we'll first need to bathe Gortash and his allies in their own blood.

82.speaker: Player
82.text: Perhaps we can reason with the leadership.

57.speaker: Wyll
57.text: Gortash, do you mean? Those metal hunks do not obey a man who sees reason.

83.speaker: Wyll
83.text: There is no negotiating with the dead gods' Chosen. They know only the language of punishment and pain.

66.speaker: Wyll
66.text: To make Baldur's Gate a safe haven, we'll first need to bathe Gortash and Orin in their own blood.

22.speaker: Player
22.text: The refugees can go elsewhere. A city in crisis has the right to secure itself.

43.speaker: Wyll
43.text: A crisis created by the same man who shut them out.

58.speaker: Wyll
58.text: Are you so heartless that you'd ask the oppressed to suffer? Are you so mindless that you don't see through blatant political scheming?

36.speaker: Wyll
36.text: Step one: Create an army and order it to march on the city. Step two: Shut the gates in the name of security. Step three: Bask in the applause.

71.speaker: Wyll
71.text: Gortash hasn't made Baldur's Gate safe - he's made it a prison. And when his army breaks through, the people will have nowhere to run.

0.speaker: Player
0.text: This is a new policy, then? Must be Gortash's doing.

91.speaker: Player
91.text: Baldur's Gate was a safe refuge when I left it. This must be Gortash's doing.

84.speaker: Narrator
84.text: *Your parasite binds your mind to Wyll's. Your memories of talking with Ravengard become his.*

72.speaker: Wyll
72.text: Incredible. To hear his voice speak those words - like a stranger wrapped in his flesh.
